mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Propaganda Model in South Korean Broadcasts
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Political Economic and Critical Discourse Analysis of News about North Korean Nuclear Tests

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study used critical political economy of communication methods to examine North Korean nuclear test coverage aired on South Korean broadcasters' prime-time news shows in South Korea. One week's news reports aired from the day of North Korea's fifth nuclear test in 2016 and the sixth in 2017. Drawing on political economic framework, this study exposed how the three filters of the Propaganda Model, ownership structure, sourcing, and anti-communism, shape the news discourses regarding the North Korean issue. A South Korean public broadcaster KBS and a South Korean privately-owned broadcaster SBS were compared. First, the review of the history of KBS and SBS revealed political economic contexts in which the two broadcasters' ownership structures have been shaped. The review particularly focused on critical political junctures in South Korean history and the broadcasters' structural changes those historical events entailed. Then, the comparison between KBS's and SBS's number of news stories during each one-week window presented the subtle but notable differences between the two broadcasters of different ownership structures. Then the news transcripts were analyzed to find sourcing patterns in covering North Korean nuclear tests. Lastly, a critical discourse analysisâ€”Discourse Historical Approach was adopted to examine anti-communism perpetuated in the portrayals of North Korea and nuclear tests. The study first found that both KBS and SBS devoted a large portion of news stories to highlight North Korea's threat and the military responses of surrounding countries. SBS produced fewer news stories than KBS, which is interpreted as the result of seeking sensationalism. Sourcing analysis revealed the heavy reliance on elite institutional sources of both broadcasters. KBS and SBS differed from each other in the political orientations of the experts interviewed in the reports. KBS consistently presented conservative experts' interviews over the two periods, while SBS interviewed more liberal pundits than conservatives in the reports. The broadcasters differed in the degree of anti-communist discourses. KBS displayed negative discourses regarding the North Korean regime and nuclear tests to a greater extent than SBS. The study concludes that the two major South Korean broadcasters overall exhibited conformity to the dominant elite group's ideology by producing news content filtered by sourcing and anti-communism.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts.
journalism, media industry, North Korean nuclear tests, political economy of communication, Propaganda Model, South Korean broadcaster
Jennifer Proffitt, Professor Directing Thesis; Stephen McDowell, Committee Member; Arienne Ferchaud, Committee Member.
